So long as Tailwind is looking at your module.html files to generate classes, you should be golden.

If you’re wanting to use Tailwind directives in your module.css files, you’ll have to add
```import "./module.css";```
to the start of your relevant module.js file. Personally, I prefer to avoid doing this, as it degrades the user experience in the page editor by requiring use of the “Apply Changes” button.

Apologies for the delay, got roped into a work call!

I realize that the create-HubSpot-project utility defaults to utilizing an older version of TailwindCSS that doesn’t feature the JIT (just-in-time) class generation functionality of later version — I had updated to a more recent version in the project files I was referencing.

It’s been a bit since I’ve used an older version of Tailwind, but if my memory serves me, you should be able to add `"./src/modules/**/*.html"` to your purge settings, and that should make it start looking for your modules’ HTML files.

With regards to using Tailwind directives — it’s generally recommended to avoid using the `@apply` directive, which is what I would expect you’d find yourself using most often in module files.

Directives you *do* want to be using when building styles with Tailwind — like the `@layer` directives — are generally focused on more global styles, so you’d want them to be in your main CSS bundle.
